Coming soon on this site: A Student Union

Goucher to house Hoppies next year
Up to fifty Hopkins men will
be housed in Goucher College
dormitories next year, under a
proposal announced yesterday by
administrators at both
institutions.
Although privately endorsed
by Presidents Steven Muller of
Hopkins and Marvin Perry of
Goucher, the plan must be
formally approved by the
trustees of both schools.
Billed as an experiment in
co-educational housing at the
previously all-female college, the
plan should help relieve the
housing shortage at Hopkins,
which one administrator called
"severe".
In announcing the plan,
Hopkins Dean of Students
Robert J. Fitzpatrick reported,
"This is not a complete solution
to our housing problems, but it is
one step that can help."
He added, "Neither institution
has made a definite committment
to do it. We're just trying to see
if there is sufficient student
interest."
Student reaction at Johns
Hopkins has been largely
favorable. Andrew Loftus,
Chairman of the Student
Council's Housing Committee,
stated, "I think it's a fantastic

Robert Fitzpatrick
idea."
Despite prohibitions which
permit only 25 Goucher seniors
to live off-campus, Goucher Dean
of Students Martha Nichols
noted a number of dormitory
vacancies this year. "This is not
just a case of tilling space," she
added.
In order for the plan to work,
Nichols stated, "We need at least
25 students. We can guarantee
space for 50 men, but anything
under 25 would be nearly
tokenism."
She indicated that additional
space, if needed, could be
obtained by allowing students to
live off-campus.
No plans to allow Goucher

women to live at Hopkins have
been disclosed. Echoing criticism
from some Goucher
undergraduates, Loftus
suggested, "I feel that they
should give all Goucher girls the
option of moving off-campus."
Ironed
Among difficulties which
would have to be ironed out
before the plan could get
underway, according to Hopkins
Director of Student Affairs
Dottie Lebo, are liberalized rules
for exchange courses,
transportation, and room and
board rates.
At present, students at either
school must obtain permission
from both schools to enroll in a
maximum of one course per
semester at the other institution.
Additional enrollment
opportunities might be necessary
under the new plan, Lebo
indicated.
Although a shuttle bus runs
the seven-mile route between the
two campuses hourly until
6:00p.m., Fitzpatrick stated that
later runs would be necessary.
Another problem is room and
board. All dormitory students at
Goucher must presently sign up
for meals, which are included in
the $1550 room and board rate.

Goucher students must pay an
additional $100 for the January
session. Two such sessions are
required for graduation.
The current rate for room and
board at Hopkins is $1375 for a
double room, and $1475 for a
single. There is no additional
charge for the January session.
Upperclassmen are not required
to pay the board fee of
approximatley $5 30.
Loftus suggested that students
would be willing to pay the
Goucher board rate, because
"Their food seems somewhat
better than ours."
'Jerry Van Voorhis, assistant to
Hopkins head resident counselor
Col. Robert Serena, reported that
additional difficulties would
involve physical facilities and
social pressures. "While there
have been almost no problems
with women adjusting to
coeducational housing at the
University. I would expect some
problems with a small minority
of men living on a predominantly
women's campus, which we don't
find here."
Women were first housed in
University dormitories in the fall
of 1971, one year after Hopkins
officially became
coeducational.

HAG meets, defers agenda to next week
By ALVIN STEIN
Disabled by lack of attendance
and organizational problems, the
first meeting of the Arts and
Sciences Advisory Council, now
named the Homewood Advisory
Council (HAC), deferred agenda
business to next week's meeting.
The meeting was attended by
Only five regular members
Including two undergraduates, a
member of the professional staff,
and two faculty members. The
Council has 13 members.

It was decided by the !JAC to
seat two Evening College
representatives on the Council.
The agenda, which was
postponed until next week's
meeting,including a discussion of
campus security problems.
Discussion at the meeting on
defining the role of the Council
and selection processes for future
members. Debate centered on
whether all factions of the
University should be represented
on the Council.

Vice-President for the Homewood Division

A brief discussion was held on
campus security problems, but
no definite statements were made
on the subject, except that the
HAC would be consulted if any
University monies were to be
distributed for security reasons.
Commenting on the lack of
attendance at the meeting, HAC
Chairman, Homewood
Vice-President .George Benton
stated, "Hopefully, the
attendance will be stronger at the
next meeting, so we can take
definite votes on these suggested
ideas."
Paul Stein, a sophomore, HAC
member, remarked, "The basic
accomplishment of the meeting
was that everyone got a basic feel
for Dr. Benton's hopes and goals
for the Council."
Andy Savitz, Student Council
President, commented, "The
graduate students and some
faculty members have not yet
been selected. Hopefully
members will be selected in the
spring of next year, so that we
can have a better start."
Benton suggested that the
group serve as an advisory body
to him in areas of non-academic
matters. "Other committees, as
the Committee on Undergraduate

made concerning lighting, phones
and a student patrol, one more
campus patrol car will be
purchased, bringing the total
number in service to two by next
July. Previously, Hopkins has had
one patrol car for use on the
Homewood campus and has used
one of the campus service
vehicles for extra patrols.
Plans currently under
discussion for improving campus
lighting include the installation
of sodium vapor lights, similar to
those at the Civic Center,
throughout the campus. Benton
indicated that he would prefer to
see the whole campus lit by
sodium vapor, rather than only
part of it. "Mixed sodium vapor
and mercury lighting is
unpleasant," he commented.

More alertness lowers attack risk
By PETER GARDNER
Speaking at a panel discussion
on rape Wednesday night, a
representative of the Baltimore
Police Department urged a group
of coeds to be more alert as they
walked around the campus,
especially after dark to reduce
the risk of being attacked.
Women Notorious
Policewoman Linda Weinstein
of the Community Relations
Division explained that "most
women are notorious for walking
around in another world,"
"They are usually completely
unalert," she commented, adding
that many victims even look
away when being attacked,
hoping that the assailant will
disappear.
Approximately 30 coeds
watched in a mixture of
amusement and concern as the
Policewoman demonstrated
various means of fending off an
attacker.
Scream
Weinstein explained that there
is both a psychological and a
physical aspect to self defense.
She repeatedly stressed that the
best way to avoid being assaulted
is to be constantly on the alert.
"Noise is the best deterrent to
any type of crime," she asserted,
adding that if someone even
looked as if he were going to
attack you, one shouldn't
hesitate to scream.
Weinstein rejected the idea of
using a whistle to attract
attention and instead suggested a
miniature air horn. The
advantage of this "weapon" she
suggested is that the attacker will

think it is a tear gas cannister.
But while the horn is a good
thing to have, the Policewoman
explained, "virtually anything
you are carrying in your hand is a
potential weapon." She
demonstrated the effectiveness of
the corner of a notebook, a
rolled up newspaper, a key and
least surprisingly, an umbrella, to
disable one's assailant.
"A book can be a terrific
weapon," she remarked,"for you
just go for the throat with the
corner of the book."

Marijuana organization seeks legalization
By SUE WOOLHISER
The National Organization for
the Reform of Marijuana Laws
(NORML) , is striving to add
respectability to the legalization
of marijuana by stressing the
extreme legal penalties for
Possession and playing down
Youth and radical support.
While complete national
legalization is the group's goal
they are also concerned with
gradual reforms of the present set
of drug laws. In addition to its
federal lobbying activities
NORML also serves as a
coordinating body for state
groups who direct specific
campaigns in their own areas.
NORML does not advocate the
use of marijuana, but stresses the
injustice of jailing innocent
persons. "The real issue is
Whether people who smoke
should go to jail or nor," said R.
Keith Stroup, executive director
of NORML.
"The ineffectiveness of the
laws is wrecking peoples
lives ,"Stroup commented. He

By RICHARD BLAND
The Milton S. Eisenhower
Library's budget to buy new
books has increased from
$350,000 to $400,000 over the
past year. There will be tew new
purchases according to Mrs.
Candida Allanbrook, a library
bibliographer.
An inflationary spiral in book
prices, combined with a
geometric increase in publication
rates was pinpointed by
Collection Development librarian
Dr. Morgan H. Pritchett as the
primary cause underlying
limitations on purchasing.
Pritchett stated that
S1,000,000 a year would be
needed to buy the books
necessary to till gaps in new
programs such as Urban Studies,

more fully satisfy the needs of
various divisions of the
University, and purchase other
books as well.
The Library buys new books
t o meet the requests of the
individual divisions and
departments of the University.
Pritchett maintained, "The
appetite of the faculty is very
high and they must order books
on a very selective basis to get
the most mileage out of their
instructional and research
needs."
65 percent of the library's
acquisitions last year were
standing orders for selected
volume series such as American
Heritage, and microfilm
requested by individual faculty
members. The other 35 percent

were for authored titles.
In the year 1970-71, the MSE
Library cut off all purchases
because of severe budget cuts
which entitled it to no extra
money.
Pritchett noted that there
wasn't enough money from the
University to buy "Luxury items
such as rare books, or books on
religion and law."
He added, though, that book
requests by students could
generally be accommodated and
that student suggestions for new
Xerox machines, repair of
vandalized clocks and other
requests for better physical
facilities had been carried out.
The Library also orders new
books for the Hutzler Reading
room at the request of students
and faculty members.
Over the past five years the
total number of volumes in the
MSE Library has increased from
,700,000 to 1,900,000. The
number of microfilms has
increased from 20,000 to 30,000
in that same period. In addition,
the number of government
documents has increased from
55,000 to 70,000. The MSE
Library is one of several official
government depositories in the
nation.

Our Council
Usually for lack of anything better to
say, many students ask me the following
question:
"What is the Student Council doing?"
This query never ceases to amaze me,
and I have yet to come up with a
satisfactory answer - either in terms of
the questioner or myself.
Many people see the Student Council,
or any governing group, as a number of
people who get together at regular
intervals and do things. This is not the
case, and I would like to set some people
straight.
Student government at Johns Hopkins
is a strange thing. The way things are set
up now, no student group has de jure
power. This is certainly not the fault of
this year's Student Council. It is because
students have allowed things to
deteriorate to the point where they were
laughed at rather than listened to.
Any influence the Student Council
may have is in its ability to convince
certain people that it has a good idea.
When it comes to dealing with important
kLiestions such as tuition or education,
cectain inembels make it theic task to get

each other for support.
Some of the most effective people
aren't on Council. They attend Council
meetings; and, in my mind, they are de
facto members of the Student Council. It
helps them get into offices.
This year's administration is faced with
a new type of "Student Leader." Nobody
is fooling themselves by thinking that the
undergraduates, by some type of
Governance report or other sorcery can
get "power" at Johns Hopkins. Lets face
it. Even the faculty don't have "power"
Academic Council is an
per se. The
advisory board. It just so happens that
they are extremely influential when it's
policy making time. This is the type of
power that exists at Hopkins.
The difference is, I think, that this
year's students are beginning to realize
this. Instead of wasting their time by
discussing what power is at Hopkins and
who has it, they're just beating on doors,
and generally making pains in the ass of,
themselves. In the process they are
getting listened to, and this is the first
step towards getting real student input at
Johns Hopkins.

University's centennial in a new student union. The

McGOVERN/SHRIVER
This Tuesday's election boils down to a choice
between men—two outlooks—two philosophies—two
ways of life. Which is more in tune N.
vith our
heritage—with today's realities and the needs of
today's world? Which inspires confidence in us as
citizens and pride in us as a nation?
Richard Nixon has spent four years presiding over
the deterioration of his "home front," vetoing
expenditures for the health and educational
opportunities of our children, while providing vast
expenditures for destruction in Southeast Asia. The
litany is too long, too frightening, and far too familiar
—unemployment, inflated prices, polluted towns and
countryside, housing shortages, racial division, crime in
both high and low places—responsibilities neglected,
opportunities ignored. A nation desperately in need of
healing has a Chief Executive expert in Saturday
football games and Sunday retreats at San Clemente,
and a Vice-President who preaches and inspires
polarization among our people. Cities, families, and
individuals decay, while the Nixon Administration
turns its back.
George McGovern stands in a long tradition of
Democratic Presidents, from Roosevelt and Truman
to Kennedy and Johnson, who have known the needs
of the American people and have taken political and
personal risks to respond to those needs. McGovern
cares about all persons—Americans and Vietnamese,
young and old, white and black, male and female. He
cares about urban decay, high unemployment,
pollution, the need for better jobs which give
workers dignity, and better schools to give quality
education to all....For George McGovern, the job of a
President is to make living good for all the people.
Americans of principle and compassion must reject
four more years of Richard Nixon, who has proven
again and again that he puts power above principle
and has no real capacity for compassion. His concern
for the real issues is appallingly absent. His concept
of leadership is to remain aloof from public and
press alike—wrapping himself in the flag and isolating
himself behind White House doors—until he moves to
dazzle us all with a TV spectacular. It won't do. It is
hollow. It is a preface to chaos.

George McGovern wants to listen and wants to
lead. He sees America for what it is and what it can
be. With George McGovern as President, we can
fulfill the great aims of the nation's founders. We can
become a better nation.

What can be done to get an effective

By MARC SOBER
In a way, it is sort of a shame that
Aaron Copeland is appearing tonight in
Shrivel- Hall, because appearing at the
same time at the Museum of Art is Frank
Capra. This is not to demean Copeland,
aliving cultural landmark, nor does it
mean that if Copeland were not at Shriver
many students would flock to see a film
director whose last really memorable film
was made before they were born.
The turnout at the Capra film festival
at the Museum during the past few
months has been surprisingly poor, with
only a few students and a couple of
discerning professors there representing
the
the Hopkins community. Since
arts are the sphere with which creativity
is most often associated, it is unfortunate
that the Eisenhower Symposium
committee did not coordiante its
ambitious undertaking with our neighbor
to the south.
True, creativity is an infinitely broad
topic, but it would have been worthwhile
to include the motion picture within the
scope of the symposium. For the film is
at once the most.complex and the least
abstract of the creative arts. It is also the
most social and technological of art
forms. Thus it touches upon many facets
of creativity covered by symposium
speakers. A film director finds a poetic

vision amenable to his own personality
and follows it in making his films;
filmaking is a creative synthesis.
Capra. at one level, represents a very
mundane kind of creativity --executive
ability. Film is a business, and as Piaget
used the logical positivists as antagonists
to spur him on. Capra used the fantastic
Hollywood producer. And in doing so he
was able to obtain total control of his
films. (His worst films were the ones
where this control was infringed upon.)
In this way he was able to combine the
,talents of great scenarists (Robert Riskin,
Sidney Buchman), great photographers
(Joseph Walker. George Barnes), great
technicians (Slavko Vorkapich), and a
company of Hollywood's greatest
character actors into a more coherent
whole than any other American director.
And in using Gary Cooper, James
Stewart, Spencer Tracy. and Walter
Huston he carved out a Hollywood Mt.
Rushmore.
Capra is usually discussed in terms of
the themes of his films (when he is
discussed at all). This can be seen in the
title given the Museum series—"Was There
Ever Really an American, or Was There
ONly Frank Capra?" He took American,
human, ideals and welded together a new
genre; what film historians call the
"fantasy of goodwill," and what both

This manuscnpt collection presents
the excitement of the early years of the
"Baltimore Experiment." It is one of the
paradoxes of declared liberalism that this
university preserves the sentiments of
men like Daniel Gilman, whose "brains,
not bricks" attitude is being violated
daily.. In one of Gilman's letters from
overseas, he records a serious observation
Oven him by a professor at the University
at Freiburg, Baden:

1 hope the trustees will not
be scandalized by their
mathematical professor having composed a poem of
201 lines, all (except five)
rhyming to "Rosalind."

Here also are Gilman's letters from the
British Isles and the continent where he
was sent in the summer of 1875 to collect
ideas. Travelling with the first of his
choices for the original faculty, Henry
Rowland, he found most of the
universities there to be out of session,
most of the professors to be on vacation,
and his own project to be "making less
progress than I could wish." He was,
however, deeply impressed, expecially by
the German institutions and did manage
to get a broad impression of the steps he
would take in structuring an American
university in the European style. It meant
steering away from strictly career oriented
education toward open-ended research,
and collecting a faculty deserving of the
opportunity to escape the then narrow
limits of American higher education.
Here, too, are the letters between
Gilamn and the original faculty members,
such as J. J. Sylvester who,in an informal
letter of acceptance, showed the type of
eclectic personality that so- much spiced
the future flavor of the Hopkins

women. "I heard the word
brother on the first show si many
times that I almost puked." she
said.
"Did you ever notice how The
Rookies managed to convert the
East-side criminals into law
abiding citizens by playing a
game of basketball with them?"
asked Bachrach. Also, she
claimed there are only three
show this season which feature
Lawyers, and Marcus Welby, "
she said. "But these were the
kind of shows where those young
hearts of the heroes went out to
the poor they didn't even know."
Bachrach cited many other
problems with these shows."The
Young Lawyers featured a
woman lawyer who could only
wiggle her ass and nothing more.
The series never showed her on a

case in court nor did the
audience ever see her questioning
women in the main roles: Maude,
Bridget Loves Bernie, and Anna
and the King.
"The title of Bridget Loves
Bernie implies that Bernie
doesn't give a man about

Bridget." She explained,"This
show should have been made
twenty years ago and have taken
place in Cairo, Egypt. Let's face
it, thereis just not that much anti
- Semitism in New York these
days."

Eastern's Leisure Class.
Sometimes it's Coach.Sometimes it's First Class.
Sometimes it's Free.
Usually you payYouth Fare and you get a
seat in Coach.
After you buy a Leisure Clasticket at the
regularYouth Fare,any ofthree things can happen.
Since Leisure Class is a Conditional
Reservation, it's possible you won't get on the flight
you made a reservation for But. if you do,you'll
usually get a seat in Coach.

IfCoach is full and First Class isn't,you
get First Class.
You'll get a seat in First Class. Drink First
Class drinks and enjoy First Class service.
And you still enjoy the Youth Fare.
11 ek of all the people who bought a Leisure
Class ticket last year got a First Class seat.

Ifthe plane is full,you spend time waiting
but no money flying.
You get a seat in the lobby.Then we refund
your money and send you off on our next flight
with an available seat. Free.
We invented Leisure Class to solve the ageold airline problem of"no shows"(people
who make reservations, but don't show up for the
flight). Since Leisure Class saves us the
money we would lose on"no shows," we don't
mind letting Leisure Class passengers save their
money when everybody does show up.
Last year,95% of the people who bought a
Leisure Class ticket got on the plane they wanted.
The rest(over 12,000 people) got a free ride.
To qualify,just make a Leisure Class
reservation as you would a reservation for First or
Coach.Then,be at the boarding gate with your Leisure Class ticket 20 minutes before flight time.
If you have to wait for a flight with an available seat, it might be anywhere from
several minutes to several hours. Of course,the number of Leisure Class reservations is limited per
flight and not available on all our flights to all destinations or on all fares. Nor when the plane itself
is grounded due to equipment,substitutions or failures or weather conditions.
So call Eastern Airlines at 768-3100. Or call your travel agent. They're the only ones who can
tell you about Leisure Class.

Jackie Robinson : his spirit lives after him
By MICHAEL BERESTON
The title Roger Kahn had
given to his book The Boys of
Summer somehow did not quite
fit the men that passed through
the quiet October crispness that
shrouded New York and
Brooklyn last Friday afternoon.
Someone had said that one of the
famed Brooklyn Dodgers' "Boys
of Summer" had died, but they
were wrong; Jackie Robinson,
the man, then mortal black
avenger who had lived in
constant warfare with man's
innermost hatred and never lost a
battle, was finally at peace with
his God

Jackie Robinson, the baseball
player, had broken in in 1946 as
part of Branch Rickey's "noble
exper ment" to intergrate major
league baseball. Robinson had
been an All-American football
player at U.C.L.A. before signing
with the Brooklyn Dodgers.
After only one year with the
Montreal Royals in which he led
the International League in
batting average amd stolen bases,
he was brought up to Brooklyn
at the age of twenty seven.
Fighting, clawing and scratching
in an environment hostile, racist,
and at first unwilling to accept
him, he won victory after victory

for himself and his people.
Robinson batted .297 his first
year in the majors, led the
National League in stolen bases
with twenty nine, and was named
rookie of the year. Two years
later, he won the Most Valuable
Player award while leading the
league in batting (.342) and
stolen bases again (thirty seven).
That same season he drove. in 124
runs while compiling a
remarkable 303 hits.
But aside from this and his
outstanding lifetime average of
.311 - Robinson was one of the
great clutch players of his era.
Time after endless time he came

page 16/news-letter/november 3, 1972

Campaign '72

The polling labyrinth: can McGovern win?
By LEON BARISH
"Peace is at hand." "Goodbye
Vietnam." These poetic headlines
were gaping at me as I came from
class this
afternoon. This
week's NewsNews
week had
arrived early (or Analysis
perhaps finally
on time) with
long reports of the impending
"peace" in Vietnam and the
upcoming elections. Having had
enough of the current rhetoric on
peace, I turned to page 40 to see
this newsweekly's pre-election
analysis. I wish I would had stuck
to peace.
Pre-election analysis is sticky
business. The analyst is dealing
with polls that can be refuted
with other polls; opinions that
can be "out-facted" by other
opinions; information that can be
"out-sourced" by other
information. In the end, what is
said before an election is of
negligible importance compared
to what is said following. But the
public demands analysis before
the fact, as they demand that
Walter Cronkite tell us who the
next president is by 7:30 within
1 percent of the vote counted.
Anyone can analyze an election
before it takes place and their
predictions are just as reliable
and "valid" as Newsweek 's or
Tom Wicker's.
The tone of this election was
unfortunately set when Toni
Eagleton was dropped from the
Democratic ticket as the Vice
Presidential nominee. Everytime
that affair is dragged through the
mud (even today the columnists
write about it) a disservice to the
campaign and the country is
performed. I even regret
mentioning the "Eagleton
Affair"now, but a clarification is
needed. If, as the argument goes,
Senator Eagleton was left on the
ticket, his health would have
been an issue throughout the
campaign. Eagleton was dropped,
as demanded, and a thorough
discussion of the issues was
expected to follow.
Unfortunately, this hasn't
happened at all. The press has
used the "Eagleton Affair" and
subsequent "mind changes" by
Senator McGovern as an excuse
for not presenting the issues
squarely before the people.
Newsweek 's analysis, which lacks
any comment on the issues, is a
glaring example of the
performance of the majority of
the media, who have focused
primarily on the personalities,
faults, attributes of the candidate
and the incumbent. The
economy, welfare reform, health
insurance, defense spending,
corruption, and other problems
which will become blackheads on
the face of America in the next
four years have been virtually
ignored. Only a few papers and
networks have shed light in the
tunnel that the media and the
incumbent are leading us
through.
The press is by no means
entirely to blame. The media's
primary responsibility is to
report what the candidates are
saying and discussing Lin addresses
before the people. Regardless of

one's bias, one must admit that
there has been no real discuaaion
between the candidates in this
,campaign. Discussion implies
dialogue between two parties of
which we have seen none.
Senator McGovern should be
commended for addressing
himself to the'fundamental issues
before us. He has been hampered,
though, by no response from the
incumbent. We have seen ,him
talking to an empty chair. No
candidate has campaigned as
little as Richard Nixon since
Warren Harding. This, by itself,
has blocked any possibility for a
good campaign or a good
election.
I have prefaced this analysis
with a look at the campaign
because, obviously, the election
is a direct result of the campaign.
Hence, if you don't have a good
campaign, you can't have a good
election. Regardless of the
winner, I view this campaign as

one that hopefully will not be
repeated for years to come.
Any pre-election analysis must
rely heavily on the polls, so. as
much as I wish I could, I cannot
deviate from this norm. But there
is one nice rule about polls
they can be used to interpret
opposite conclusions. I will
employ this "rule of opposite
conclusions" liberally in the next
few paragraphs.
There are four sets of data
‘vhich are of interest in the
closing week of this campaign.
The last New York
TimeslYankelovich poll gives
Nixon 56% and McGovern 30%
of the vote. The 'latest Gallup
poll has Nixon receiving 59% of'
the vote and McGovern 36%. The
aggegate count of Newsweek 's six
key states (California, Illinois,
Michigan, New York. Ohio. and
Pennsylvania) is 57% - 38% with
Nixon again the leader. The key
poll (for this analysis) is a recent

Sindlinger poll suggesting that
only 59% of Nixon's backers plan
to vote while 91% of the.
McGovern prospects plan to pull
the lever. If this data is accurate
We can interpolate the figures
into the other polls and come up
with perhaps more accurate
results.
When we compute the
Times/Yankehmich poll we find
things have changed a lot - 47%
for Nixon and 38% for McGovern
with a large percentage
undecided. A new Gallup poll
works out to 49.7% for Nixon
and 46.8% for McGovern. The .
election gets closer yet.
Newsweek 's six state poll. with
the Sindlinger influence tips in
favor of McGovern who recieves
49.4%. of the vote to Nixon's
48%. All you McGovern
supporters should not start
proclaiming victory. These
figures are largely conjecture and
a re based solely on the accuracy

Nixon stumps in key Senate races
President Nixon's plans to
stump this weekend in several
states with key Senate races may
well indicate that Republican
control of the next Senate is
farther from reality than most
Republican soothsayers once
projected.
Nixon will travel to Rhode
Island, Oklahoma, North
Carolina, and New Mexico before
retreating to the Western White
House for election day. Each of
these states have Senate seats
Republicans are banking on for
control in the 93rd upper house.
Off 33 Senate seats up for
contention, Republicans now
hold 19, and need a net gain of 6
(or five if Nixon wins re-election
allowing Vice-President Spiro
Agnew to break a 50-50 tie) .
Last week Nixon stopped over
in Kentucky to aid former
Republican Governor Louie
Nunn,who now has the edge over
Democratic state house majority
leader Walter Huddleson.
Re tiring Re publican Senator
John Sherman Cooper's seat
must be won by Nunn for
Republican hopes to stay alive.
Latest polls give Nunn a 2
percent lead with more than 20
percent undecided.
Ahead
In Rhode Island, the state's
largest newspaper published a
poll yesterday showing
Democratic incumbent Claiborne
Pell ahead of former Governor
John Chafee 42 - 40 with 18
Percent undecided. The
Providence Journal poll had
earlier shown. Chafee a 2 -1
favorite. The race is still too close
to call, but significant in the
poll's findings is a substantial
return of Democrats to the fold
in the Senate races. The Chafee
family owns 50 percent of the
Journal and editors are planning
to endorse one of the two
candidates this Sunday; In
Oklahoma, whose Senator Fred
Harris briefly a presidential
candidate retired after one term,
Tulsa oil executive and former
Republican Governor Dewey
Bartlet is giving slightly favored

Congressman Ed 1::dinondson
stiff challenge. Polls show that
Nick Galifianakis, the
De in °erotic Congressman who
defeated Senator B. Everett
Jordon in North Carolina's senate
primary, leads a conservative
Republican challenger Jesse
Helms. Helms, who earlier this
year criticized Nixon for
"appeasing Red China" is
reaching out for his coattails.

The contest for Democratic
Senator Clinton Anderson'S seat
in New Mexico is as close as the
Pell - Chafee race. Democrat Jack
Daniels and Republican Pete
Domenici are neck and neck in a
state Nixon lost in 1960 and won
in '68, though some observers
have given Domenici a slight
edge.
The President will jump
headlong into these four Senate
races t od ay and tomorrow,
extending his coattails the extra
inches that inay yield votes for
GOP candidates from traditional
Democrats dissatisfied with the
McGovern party. Just how
deeply Nixon's appeal extends
below the Presidential level
remains to be seen.
The President's avoidance of
the Texas Senais facing a tough
race against Connally supported
De m oc rat Barefoot Saunders,
indicates the careful
orchestration of the whole
Republican effort in 1972.

of the Sindlinger poll which is
subject to as much questioning as
any other poll. But these new
figures do point to an election
much tighter than Newsweek and
most others would have us
believe. In the end, a landslide or
a close election hinges primarily
on voter interpretation of the
other article in this week's
Nelvsweek.
Conventional wisdom tells us
that any major foreign policy
initiative by an incumbent
President running for reelection
is good for several points in the
polls. The latest Harris poll seems
to confirm this rule. However,
the rule of opposite conclusions
again rears its ugly head. The
peace initiative can do several
things. First, it can appear as a
purely political move on the part
of the President. Second, voters
might wonder, as does George
McGovern, why the settlement
didn't come four years ago. ABC
News found both these
interpretations prevalent in their
.All -American city, Columbus,
Ohio. The third important
viewpoint is that voters will now
see the election in more
traditional economic terms, now
that the war is apparently really
ending. Here McGovern has the
edge in the polls and voters may
now turn to him. Again, these
are only
in
conjecture, but then any
pre -el cc lion analysis is. These
factors do, however, indicate we
may see a closer election Tuesday
night.
After all the polls are taken,
only one will mean anything at
all
the election on November
7. If Mr. Nixon wins in a
landslide, I reserve the right to be
wrong and chalk it up to
"statistical error" and admitted
optimism. If I am correct and it
is a close election, I claim the
prediction now and chalk it up to
keen analysis, admitted optimism
and, most of all, pure luck. At
any rate, I won't be turning the
tubes off at 7:30 on Tuesday
night. I suggest you shouldn't
either.

Shriver winds up Md. campaign
With only live days left in the
'72 Presidential campaign,
Sargent Shriver came to
Baltimore yesterday to make a
final pith for the Democratic
ticket in the metropolitan area.
Tile Democratic
Vice -Presidential nominee
addressed a group of clergymen,
spoke to a noontime rally at
Charles Center, and participated
in a 90th Birthday party for his
mother in the Mechanic Theatre.
Surrounded by labor and
political leaders from Maryland,
Shriver. told the Charles Center
crown to keep working hard in
order to achieve an upset victory
next Tuesday over President
Nixon.
"Don't be fainthearted," the
Vice-Presidential hopeful told the
small but enthusiastic audience.
"Gallup predicted that Trudeau
would win by 20 percent in
Canada Monday, and he lost the
whole race."

Shriver attacked the deception
of the Nixon Administration.
"On Halloween, Nixon and his
crown had a chance to play trick
or treat. Next Tuesday, we're
going to make him play truth or
consequences,"lie exclaimed.
Shriver also criticized the
tentative Vietnam peace
agreement as offering nothing to
any of the conflicting interests
on the war. "There's no military
victory for those who wanted
one, no bombing halt .for those
who wanted that, no cease-fire
for those who wanted one, no
guaranteed future for Vietnam
for those who wanted it, no
Democratic regime in the South
for those who wanted that, no
sign of a North Vietnamese
surrender for those who wanted
one...No matter what you want,
Nixon has failed to deliver,"
commented Shriver.
Calling the President the "veto
expert of the half-century", the
Democratic hopeful compared

Nixon with South Vietnamese
President Thieu. "Nixon saysq
won't sign', Thicu says 'I won't
sign';" declared Shriver," the
two masters of the veto have
found each other."
Following the rally, the
Shriver entourage entered the
Morris Mechanic Theatre for a
gala birthday celebration for
Hilda Shriver, the candidate's
mother. Billed as a nonpartisan
event, the theatre was filled with
guests invited for a combination
Senior Citizens Rally and
Birthday Party.
Folksinger Theodore Bikel
who acted as Master of
Ceremonies, was one of manY
who was entertaining the groupGovernor Marvin Mandel and
Mayor William Donald Schaefer
were on hand with proclamations
honoring Mrs. Shriver. Schaefer,
a Democrat, has refrained from
endorsing the McGovem—Shriver
ticket.

Coming soon on this site: A Student Union

Goucher to house Hoppies next year
Up to fifty Hopkins men will
be housed in Goucher College
dormitories next year, under a
proposal announced yesterday by
administrators at both
institutions.
Although privately endorsed
by Presidents Steven Muller of
Hopkins and Marvin Perry of
Goucher, the plan must be
formally approved by the
trustees of both schools.
Billed as an experiment in
co-educational housing at the
previously all-female college, the
plan should help relieve the
housing shortage at Hopkins,
which one administrator called
"severe".
In announcing the plan,
Hopkins Dean of Students
Robert J. Fitzpatrick reported,
"This is not a complete solution
to our housing problems, but it is
one step that can help."
He added, "Neither institution
has made a definite committment
to do it. We're just trying to see
if there is sufficient student
interest."
Student reaction at Johns
Hopkins has been largely
favorable. Andrew Loftus,
Chairman of the Student
Council's Housing Committee,
stated, "I think it's a fantastic

Robert Fitzpatrick
idea."
Despite prohibitions which
permit only 25 Goucher seniors
to live off-campus, Goucher Dean
of Students Martha Nichols
noted a number of dormitory
vacancies this year. "This is not
just a case of tilling space," she
added.
In order for the plan to work,
Nichols stated, "We need at least
25 students. We can guarantee
space for 50 men, but anything
under 25 would be nearly
tokenism."
She indicated that additional
space, if needed, could be
obtained by allowing students to
live off-campus.
No plans to allow Goucher

women to live at Hopkins have
been disclosed. Echoing criticism
from some Goucher
undergraduates, Loftus
suggested, "I feel that they
should give all Goucher girls the
option of moving off-campus."
Ironed
Among difficulties which
would have to be ironed out
before the plan could get
underway, according to Hopkins
Director of Student Affairs
Dottie Lebo, are liberalized rules
for exchange courses,
transportation, and room and
board rates.
At present, students at either
school must obtain permission
from both schools to enroll in a
maximum of one course per
semester at the other institution.
Additional enrollment
opportunities might be necessary
under the new plan, Lebo
indicated.
Although a shuttle bus runs
the seven-mile route between the
two campuses hourly until
6:00p.m., Fitzpatrick stated that
later runs would be necessary.
Another problem is room and
board. All dormitory students at
Goucher must presently sign up
for meals, which are included in
the $1550 room and board rate.

Goucher students must pay an
additional $100 for the January
session. Two such sessions are
required for graduation.
The current rate for room and
board at Hopkins is $1375 for a
double room, and $1475 for a
single. There is no additional
charge for the January session.
Upperclassmen are not required
to pay the board fee of
approximatley $5 30.
Loftus suggested that students
would be willing to pay the
Goucher board rate, because
"Their food seems somewhat
better than ours."
'Jerry Van Voorhis, assistant to
Hopkins head resident counselor
Col. Robert Serena, reported that
additional difficulties would
involve physical facilities and
social pressures. "While there
have been almost no problems
with women adjusting to
coeducational housing at the
University. I would expect some
problems with a small minority
of men living on a predominantly
women's campus, which we don't
find here."
Women were first housed in
University dormitories in the fall
of 1971, one year after Hopkins
officially became
coeducational.

More alertness lowers attack risk
By PETER GARDNER
Speaking at a panel discussion
on rape Wednesday night, a
representative of the Baltimore
Police Department urged a group
of coeds to be more alert as they
walked around the campus,
especially after dark to reduce
the risk of being attacked.
Women Notorious
Policewoman Linda Weinstein
of the Community Relations
Division explained that "most
women are notorious for walking
around in another world,"
"They are usually completely
unalert," she commented, adding
that many victims even look
away when being attacked,
hoping that the assailant will
disappear.
Approximately 30 coeds
watched in a mixture of
amusement and concern as the
Policewoman demonstrated
various means of fending off an
attacker.
Scream
Weinstein explained that there
is both a psychological and a
physical aspect to self defense.
She repeatedly stressed that the
best way to avoid being assaulted
is to be constantly on the alert.
"Noise is the best deterrent to
any type of crime," she asserted,
adding that if someone even
looked as if he were going to
attack you, one shouldn't
hesitate to scream.
Weinstein rejected the idea of
using a whistle to attract
attention and instead suggested a
miniature air horn. The
advantage of this "weapon" she
suggested is that the attacker will

think it is a tear gas cannister.
But while the horn is a good
thing to have, the Policewoman
explained, "virtually anything
you are carrying in your hand is a
potential weapon." She
demonstrated the effectiveness of
the corner of a notebook, a
rolled up newspaper, a key and
least surprisingly, an umbrella, to
disable one's assailant.
"A book can be a terrific
weapon," she remarked,"for you
just go for the throat with the
corner of the book."

In addition, Barnes said, "The

He also criticized the creator's

the world of i 972," he said. He

should be, that ne needs to work

from behind, but that it was

"An elbow to the mid section
or raised to the face is usually

Guarantee
Weinstein suggested an even
better escape if the others did

stretch out one's arm, make a

attacker's groin. "I guarantee

Marijuana organization seeks legalization
By SUE WOOLHISER
The National Organization for
the Reform of Marijuana Laws
(NORML) , is striving to add
respectability to the legalization
of marijuana by stressing the
extreme legal penalties for
Possession and playing down
Youth and radical support.
While complete national
legalization is the group's goal
they are also concerned with
gradual reforms of the present set
of drug laws. In addition to its
federal lobbying activities
NORML also serves as a
coordinating body for state
groups who direct specific
campaigns in their own areas.
NORML does not advocate the
use of marijuana, but stresses the
injustice of jailing innocent
persons. "The real issue is
Whether people who smoke
should go to jail or nor," said R.
Keith Stroup, executive director
of NORML.
"The ineffectiveness of the
laws is wrecking peoples
lives ,"Stroup commented. He

By RICHARD BLAND
The Milton S. Eisenhower
Library's budget to buy new
books has increased from
$350,000 to $400,000 over the
past year. There will be tew new
purchases according to Mrs.
Candida Allanbrook, a library
bibliographer.
An inflationary spiral in book
prices, combined with a
geometric increase in publication
rates was pinpointed by
Collection Development librarian
Dr. Morgan H. Pritchett as the
primary cause underlying
limitations on purchasing.
Pritchett stated that
S1,000,000 a year would be
needed to buy the books
necessary to till gaps in new
programs such as Urban Studies,

more fully satisfy the needs of
various divisions of the
University, and purchase other
books as well.
The Library buys new books
t o meet the requests of the
individual divisions and
departments of the University.
Pritchett maintained, "The
appetite of the faculty is very
high and they must order books
on a very selective basis to get
the most mileage out of their
instructional and research
needs."
65 percent of the library's
acquisitions last year were
standing orders for selected
volume series such as American
Heritage, and microfilm
requested by individual faculty
members. The other 35 percent

were for authored titles.
In the year 1970-71, the MSE
Library cut off all purchases
because of severe budget cuts
which entitled it to no extra
money.
Pritchett noted that there
wasn't enough money from the
University to buy "Luxury items
such as rare books, or books on
religion and law."
He added, though, that book
requests by students could
generally be accommodated and
that student suggestions for new
Xerox machines, repair of
vandalized clocks and other
requests for better physical
facilities had been carried out.
The Library also orders new
books for the Hutzler Reading
room at the request of students
and faculty members.
Over the past five years the
total number of volumes in the
MSE Library has increased from
,700,000 to 1,900,000. The
number of microfilms has
increased from 20,000 to 30,000
in that same period. In addition,
the number of government
documents has increased from
55,000 to 70,000. The MSE
Library is one of several official
government depositories in the
nation.

Our Council
Usually for lack of anything better to
say, many students ask me the following
question:
"What is the Student Council doing?"
This query never ceases to amaze me,
and I have yet to come up with a
satisfactory answer - either in terms of
the questioner or myself.
Many people see the Student Council,
or any governing group, as a number of
people who get together at regular
intervals and do things. This is not the
case, and I would like to set some people
straight.
Student government at Johns Hopkins
is a strange thing. The way things are set
up now, no student group has de jure
power. This is certainly not the fault of
this year's Student Council. It is because
students have allowed things to
deteriorate to the point where they were
laughed at rather than listened to.
Any influence the Student Council
may have is in its ability to convince
certain people that it has a good idea.
When it comes to dealing with important
kLiestions such as tuition or education,
cectain inembels make it theic task to get

each other for support.
Some of the most effective people
aren't on Council. They attend Council
meetings; and, in my mind, they are de
facto members of the Student Council. It
helps them get into offices.
This year's administration is faced with
a new type of "Student Leader." Nobody
is fooling themselves by thinking that the
undergraduates, by some type of
Governance report or other sorcery can
get "power" at Johns Hopkins. Lets face
it. Even the faculty don't have "power"
Academic Council is an
per se. The
advisory board. It just so happens that
they are extremely influential when it's
policy making time. This is the type of
power that exists at Hopkins.
The difference is, I think, that this
year's students are beginning to realize
this. Instead of wasting their time by
discussing what power is at Hopkins and
who has it, they're just beating on doors,
and generally making pains in the ass of,
themselves. In the process they are
getting listened to, and this is the first
step towards getting real student input at
Johns Hopkins.

construction bids, as well as possible delays due to
strikes, bad weather, more hidden sewer lines.
This is to say nothing of other questions that should
be asked. If the solicitors of the construction bids
manage to underestimate the lowest bid by one third,
what can be said of the University's ability to manage
construction itself: If the same architect who delayed
the proj, zt three weeks by not submitting working
drawings on time is to redesign the structure, will it be
done by 1976: And what purpose is served by
expediently dropping esthetic features of the building
simply to lower the cost?
It would certainly be a shame if the long needed
student union at Hopkins were to be delayed or even
scuttled due to mismanagement and sloppy planning
on the part of the University. And there is certainly no
excuse for Hopkins. now starting a $200 million fund
drive, to decide it cannot afford the extra $.344,000
required to meet the lowest bid.

McGOVERN/SHRIVER
This Tuesday's election boils down to a choice
between men—two outlooks—two philosophies—two
ways of life. Which is more in tune N.
vith our
heritage—with today's realities and the needs of
today's world? Which inspires confidence in us as
citizens and pride in us as a nation?
Richard Nixon has spent four years presiding over
the deterioration of his "home front," vetoing
expenditures for the health and educational
opportunities of our children, while providing vast
expenditures for destruction in Southeast Asia. The
litany is too long, too frightening, and far too familiar
—unemployment, inflated prices, polluted towns and
countryside, housing shortages, racial division, crime in
both high and low places—responsibilities neglected,
opportunities ignored. A nation desperately in need of
healing has a Chief Executive expert in Saturday
football games and Sunday retreats at San Clemente,
and a Vice-President who preaches and inspires
polarization among our people. Cities, families, and
individuals decay, while the Nixon Administration
turns its back.
George McGovern stands in a long tradition of
Democratic Presidents, from Roosevelt and Truman
to Kennedy and Johnson, who have known the needs
of the American people and have taken political and
personal risks to respond to those needs. McGovern
cares about all persons—Americans and Vietnamese,
young and old, white and black, male and female. He
cares about urban decay, high unemployment,
pollution, the need for better jobs which give
workers dignity, and better schools to give quality
education to all....For George McGovern, the job of a
President is to make living good for all the people.
Americans of principle and compassion must reject
four more years of Richard Nixon, who has proven
again and again that he puts power above principle
and has no real capacity for compassion. His concern
for the real issues is appallingly absent. His concept
of leadership is to remain aloof from public and
press alike—wrapping himself in the flag and isolating
himself behind White House doors—until he moves to
dazzle us all with a TV spectacular. It won't do. It is
hollow. It is a preface to chaos.

George McGovern wants to listen and wants to
lead. He sees America for what it is and what it can
be. With George McGovern as President, we can
fulfill the great aims of the nation's founders. We can
become a better nation.

By MARC SOBER
In a way, it is sort of a shame that
Aaron Copeland is appearing tonight in
Shrivel- Hall, because appearing at the
same time at the Museum of Art is Frank
Capra. This is not to demean Copeland,
aliving cultural landmark, nor does it
mean that if Copeland were not at Shriver
many students would flock to see a film
director whose last really memorable film
was made before they were born.
The turnout at the Capra film festival
at the Museum during the past few
months has been surprisingly poor, with
only a few students and a couple of
discerning professors there representing
the
the Hopkins community. Since
arts are the sphere with which creativity
is most often associated, it is unfortunate
that the Eisenhower Symposium
committee did not coordiante its
ambitious undertaking with our neighbor
to the south.
True, creativity is an infinitely broad
topic, but it would have been worthwhile
to include the motion picture within the
scope of the symposium. For the film is
at once the most.complex and the least
abstract of the creative arts. It is also the
most social and technological of art
forms. Thus it touches upon many facets
of creativity covered by symposium
speakers. A film director finds a poetic

vision amenable to his own personality
and follows it in making his films;
filmaking is a creative synthesis.
Capra. at one level, represents a very
mundane kind of creativity --executive
ability. Film is a business, and as Piaget
used the logical positivists as antagonists
to spur him on. Capra used the fantastic
Hollywood producer. And in doing so he
was able to obtain total control of his
films. (His worst films were the ones
where this control was infringed upon.)
In this way he was able to combine the
,talents of great scenarists (Robert Riskin,
Sidney Buchman), great photographers
(Joseph Walker. George Barnes), great
technicians (Slavko Vorkapich), and a
company of Hollywood's greatest
character actors into a more coherent
whole than any other American director.
And in using Gary Cooper, James
Stewart, Spencer Tracy. and Walter
Huston he carved out a Hollywood Mt.
Rushmore.
Capra is usually discussed in terms of
the themes of his films (when he is
discussed at all). This can be seen in the
title given the Museum series—"Was There
Ever Really an American, or Was There
ONly Frank Capra?" He took American,
human, ideals and welded together a new
genre; what film historians call the
"fantasy of goodwill," and what both

This manuscnpt collection presents

"Baltimore Experiment." It is one of the
paradoxes of declared liberalism that this
university preserves the sentiments of
men like Daniel Gilman, whose "brains,
not bricks" attitude is being violated
daily.. In one of Gilman's letters from
overseas, he records a serious observation
Oven him by a professor at the University
at Freiburg, Baden:

1 hope the trustees will not
be scandalized by their
mathematical professor having composed a poem of
201 lines, all (except five)
rhyming to "Rosalind."

Here also are Gilman's letters from the
British Isles and the continent where he
was sent in the summer of 1875 to collect
ideas. Travelling with the first of his
choices for the original faculty, Henry
Rowland, he found most of the
universities there to be out of session,
most of the professors to be on vacation,
and his own project to be "making less
progress than I could wish." He was,
however, deeply impressed, expecially by
the German institutions and did manage
to get a broad impression of the steps he
would take in structuring an American
university in the European style. It meant
steering away from strictly career oriented
education toward open-ended research,
and collecting a faculty deserving of the
opportunity to escape the then narrow
limits of American higher education.
Here, too, are the letters between
Gilamn and the original faculty members,
such as J. J. Sylvester who,in an informal
letter of acceptance, showed the type of
eclectic personality that so- much spiced
the future flavor of the Hopkins

Eastern's Leisure Class.
Sometimes it's Coach.Sometimes it's First Class.
Sometimes it's Free.
Usually you payYouth Fare and you get a
seat in Coach.
After you buy a Leisure Clasticket at the
regularYouth Fare,any ofthree things can happen.
Since Leisure Class is a Conditional
Reservation, it's possible you won't get on the flight
you made a reservation for But. if you do,you'll
usually get a seat in Coach.

IfCoach is full and First Class isn't,you
get First Class.
You'll get a seat in First Class. Drink First
Class drinks and enjoy First Class service.
And you still enjoy the Youth Fare.
11 ek of all the people who bought a Leisure
Class ticket last year got a First Class seat.

Ifthe plane is full,you spend time waiting
but no money flying.
You get a seat in the lobby.Then we refund
your money and send you off on our next flight
with an available seat. Free.
We invented Leisure Class to solve the ageold airline problem of"no shows"(people
who make reservations, but don't show up for the
flight). Since Leisure Class saves us the
money we would lose on"no shows," we don't
mind letting Leisure Class passengers save their
money when everybody does show up.
Last year,95% of the people who bought a
Leisure Class ticket got on the plane they wanted.
The rest(over 12,000 people) got a free ride.
To qualify,just make a Leisure Class
reservation as you would a reservation for First or
Coach.Then,be at the boarding gate with your Leisure Class ticket 20 minutes before flight time.
If you have to wait for a flight with an available seat, it might be anywhere from
several minutes to several hours. Of course,the number of Leisure Class reservations is limited per
flight and not available on all our flights to all destinations or on all fares. Nor when the plane itself
is grounded due to equipment,substitutions or failures or weather conditions.
So call Eastern Airlines at 768-3100. Or call your travel agent. They're the only ones who can
tell you about Leisure Class.

Jackie Robinson : his spirit lives after him
By MICHAEL BERESTON
The title Roger Kahn had
given to his book The Boys of
Summer somehow did not quite
fit the men that passed through
the quiet October crispness that
shrouded New York and
Brooklyn last Friday afternoon.
Someone had said that one of the
famed Brooklyn Dodgers' "Boys
of Summer" had died, but they
were wrong; Jackie Robinson,
the man, then mortal black
avenger who had lived in
constant warfare with man's
innermost hatred and never lost a
battle, was finally at peace with
his God

Jackie Robinson, the baseball
player, had broken in in 1946 as
part of Branch Rickey's "noble
exper ment" to intergrate major
league baseball. Robinson had
been an All-American football
player at U.C.L.A. before signing
with the Brooklyn Dodgers.
After only one year with the
Montreal Royals in which he led
the International League in
batting average amd stolen bases,
he was brought up to Brooklyn
at the age of twenty seven.
Fighting, clawing and scratching
in an environment hostile, racist,
and at first unwilling to accept
him, he won victory after victory

for himself and his people.
Robinson batted .297 his first
year in the majors, led the
National League in stolen bases
with twenty nine, and was named
rookie of the year. Two years
later, he won the Most Valuable
Player award while leading the
league in batting (.342) and
stolen bases again (thirty seven).
That same season he drove. in 124
runs while compiling a
remarkable 303 hits.
But aside from this and his
outstanding lifetime average of
.311 - Robinson was one of the
great clutch players of his era.
Time after endless time he came

Even after his playing days

infectious spirit that nourished
and revitalized an entire race, will
live on. In a day when man is in
increasing need of heroes, the
leadership and courage of Jack
Roosevelt Robinson is legendary.

Campaign '72

The polling labyrinth: can McGovern win?
By LEON BARISH
"Peace is at hand." "Goodbye
Vietnam." These poetic headlines
were gaping at me as I came from
class this
afternoon. This
week's NewsNews
week had
arrived early (or Analysis
perhaps finally
on time) with
long reports of the impending
"peace" in Vietnam and the
upcoming elections. Having had
enough of the current rhetoric on
peace, I turned to page 40 to see
this newsweekly's pre-election
analysis. I wish I would had stuck
to peace.
Pre-election analysis is sticky
business. The analyst is dealing
with polls that can be refuted
with other polls; opinions that
can be "out-facted" by other
opinions; information that can be
"out-sourced" by other
information. In the end, what is
said before an election is of
negligible importance compared
to what is said following. But the
public demands analysis before
the fact, as they demand that
Walter Cronkite tell us who the
next president is by 7:30 within
1 percent of the vote counted.
Anyone can analyze an election
before it takes place and their
predictions are just as reliable
and "valid" as Newsweek 's or
Tom Wicker's.
The tone of this election was
unfortunately set when Toni
Eagleton was dropped from the
Democratic ticket as the Vice
Presidential nominee. Everytime
that affair is dragged through the
mud (even today the columnists
write about it) a disservice to the
campaign and the country is
performed. I even regret
mentioning the "Eagleton
Affair"now, but a clarification is
needed. If, as the argument goes,
Senator Eagleton was left on the
ticket, his health would have
been an issue throughout the
campaign. Eagleton was dropped,
as demanded, and a thorough
discussion of the issues was
expected to follow.
Unfortunately, this hasn't
happened at all. The press has
used the "Eagleton Affair" and
subsequent "mind changes" by
Senator McGovern as an excuse
for not presenting the issues
squarely before the people.
Newsweek 's analysis, which lacks
any comment on the issues, is a
glaring example of the
performance of the majority of
the media, who have focused
primarily on the personalities,
faults, attributes of the candidate
and the incumbent. The
economy, welfare reform, health
insurance, defense spending,
corruption, and other problems
which will become blackheads on
the face of America in the next
four years have been virtually
ignored. Only a few papers and
networks have shed light in the
tunnel that the media and the
incumbent are leading us
through.
The press is by no means
entirely to blame. The media's
primary responsibility is to
report what the candidates are
saying and discussing Lin addresses
before the people. Regardless of

one's bias, one must admit that
there has been no real discuaaion
between the candidates in this
,campaign. Discussion implies
dialogue between two parties of
which we have seen none.
Senator McGovern should be
commended for addressing
himself to the'fundamental issues
before us. He has been hampered,
though, by no response from the
incumbent. We have seen ,him
talking to an empty chair. No
candidate has campaigned as
little as Richard Nixon since
Warren Harding. This, by itself,
has blocked any possibility for a
good campaign or a good
election.
I have prefaced this analysis
with a look at the campaign
because, obviously, the election
is a direct result of the campaign.
Hence, if you don't have a good
campaign, you can't have a good
election. Regardless of the
winner, I view this campaign as

one that hopefully will not be
repeated for years to come.
Any pre-election analysis must
rely heavily on the polls, so. as
much as I wish I could, I cannot
deviate from this norm. But there
is one nice rule about polls
they can be used to interpret
opposite conclusions. I will
employ this "rule of opposite
conclusions" liberally in the next
few paragraphs.
There are four sets of data
‘vhich are of interest in the
closing week of this campaign.
The last New York
TimeslYankelovich poll gives
Nixon 56% and McGovern 30%
of the vote. The 'latest Gallup
poll has Nixon receiving 59% of'
the vote and McGovern 36%. The
aggegate count of Newsweek 's six
key states (California, Illinois,
Michigan, New York. Ohio. and
Pennsylvania) is 57% - 38% with
Nixon again the leader. The key
poll (for this analysis) is a recent

Sindlinger poll suggesting that
only 59% of Nixon's backers plan
to vote while 91% of the.
McGovern prospects plan to pull
the lever. If this data is accurate
We can interpolate the figures
into the other polls and come up
with perhaps more accurate
results.
When we compute the
Times/Yankehmich poll we find
things have changed a lot - 47%
for Nixon and 38% for McGovern
with a large percentage
undecided. A new Gallup poll
works out to 49.7% for Nixon
and 46.8% for McGovern. The .
election gets closer yet.
Newsweek 's six state poll. with
the Sindlinger influence tips in
favor of McGovern who recieves
49.4%. of the vote to Nixon's
48%. All you McGovern
supporters should not start
proclaiming victory. These
figures are largely conjecture and
a re based solely on the accuracy

Nixon stumps in key Senate races
President Nixon's plans to
stump this weekend in several
states with key Senate races may
well indicate that Republican
control of the next Senate is
farther from reality than most
Republican soothsayers once
projected.
Nixon will travel to Rhode
Island, Oklahoma, North
Carolina, and New Mexico before
retreating to the Western White
House for election day. Each of
these states have Senate seats
Republicans are banking on for
control in the 93rd upper house.
Off 33 Senate seats up for
contention, Republicans now
hold 19, and need a net gain of 6
(or five if Nixon wins re-election
allowing Vice-President Spiro
Agnew to break a 50-50 tie) .
Last week Nixon stopped over
in Kentucky to aid former
Republican Governor Louie
Nunn,who now has the edge over
Democratic state house majority
leader Walter Huddleson.
Re tiring Re publican Senator
John Sherman Cooper's seat
must be won by Nunn for
Republican hopes to stay alive.
Latest polls give Nunn a 2
percent lead with more than 20
percent undecided.
Ahead
In Rhode Island, the state's
largest newspaper published a
poll yesterday showing
Democratic incumbent Claiborne
Pell ahead of former Governor
John Chafee 42 - 40 with 18
Percent undecided. The
Providence Journal poll had
earlier shown. Chafee a 2 -1
favorite. The race is still too close
to call, but significant in the
poll's findings is a substantial
return of Democrats to the fold
in the Senate races. The Chafee
family owns 50 percent of the
Journal and editors are planning
to endorse one of the two
candidates this Sunday; In
Oklahoma, whose Senator Fred
Harris briefly a presidential
candidate retired after one term,
Tulsa oil executive and former
Republican Governor Dewey
Bartlet is giving slightly favored

Congressman Ed 1::dinondson
stiff challenge. Polls show that
Nick Galifianakis, the
De in °erotic Congressman who
defeated Senator B. Everett
Jordon in North Carolina's senate
primary, leads a conservative
Republican challenger Jesse
Helms. Helms, who earlier this
year criticized Nixon for
"appeasing Red China" is
reaching out for his coattails.

The contest for Democratic
Senator Clinton Anderson'S seat
in New Mexico is as close as the
Pell - Chafee race. Democrat Jack
Daniels and Republican Pete
Domenici are neck and neck in a
state Nixon lost in 1960 and won
in '68, though some observers
have given Domenici a slight
edge.
The President will jump
headlong into these four Senate
races t od ay and tomorrow,
extending his coattails the extra
inches that inay yield votes for
GOP candidates from traditional
Democrats dissatisfied with the
McGovern party. Just how
deeply Nixon's appeal extends
below the Presidential level
remains to be seen.
The President's avoidance of
the Texas Senais facing a tough
race against Connally supported
De m oc rat Barefoot Saunders,
indicates the careful
orchestration of the whole
Republican effort in 1972.

of the Sindlinger poll which is
subject to as much questioning as
any other poll. But these new
figures do point to an election
much tighter than Newsweek and
most others would have us
believe. In the end, a landslide or
a close election hinges primarily
on voter interpretation of the
other article in this week's
Nelvsweek.
Conventional wisdom tells us
that any major foreign policy
initiative by an incumbent
President running for reelection
is good for several points in the
polls. The latest Harris poll seems
to confirm this rule. However,
the rule of opposite conclusions
again rears its ugly head. The
peace initiative can do several
things. First, it can appear as a
purely political move on the part
of the President. Second, voters
might wonder, as does George
McGovern, why the settlement
didn't come four years ago. ABC
News found both these
interpretations prevalent in their
.All -American city, Columbus,
Ohio. The third important
viewpoint is that voters will now
see the election in more
traditional economic terms, now
that the war is apparently really
ending. Here McGovern has the
edge in the polls and voters may
now turn to him. Again, these
are only
in
conjecture, but then any
pre -el cc lion analysis is. These
factors do, however, indicate we
may see a closer election Tuesday
night.
After all the polls are taken,
only one will mean anything at
all
the election on November
7. If Mr. Nixon wins in a
landslide, I reserve the right to be
wrong and chalk it up to
"statistical error" and admitted
optimism. If I am correct and it
is a close election, I claim the
prediction now and chalk it up to
keen analysis, admitted optimism
and, most of all, pure luck. At
any rate, I won't be turning the
tubes off at 7:30 on Tuesday
night. I suggest you shouldn't
either.

Shriver winds up Md. campaign
With only live days left in the
'72 Presidential campaign,
Sargent Shriver came to
Baltimore yesterday to make a
final pith for the Democratic
ticket in the metropolitan area.
Tile Democratic
Vice -Presidential nominee
addressed a group of clergymen,
spoke to a noontime rally at
Charles Center, and participated
in a 90th Birthday party for his
mother in the Mechanic Theatre.
Surrounded by labor and
political leaders from Maryland,
Shriver. told the Charles Center
crown to keep working hard in
order to achieve an upset victory
next Tuesday over President
Nixon.
"Don't be fainthearted," the
Vice-Presidential hopeful told the
small but enthusiastic audience.
"Gallup predicted that Trudeau
would win by 20 percent in
Canada Monday, and he lost the
whole race."

Shriver attacked the deception
of the Nixon Administration.
"On Halloween, Nixon and his
crown had a chance to play trick
or treat. Next Tuesday, we're
going to make him play truth or
consequences,"lie exclaimed.
Shriver also criticized the
tentative Vietnam peace
agreement as offering nothing to
any of the conflicting interests
on the war. "There's no military
victory for those who wanted
one, no bombing halt .for those
who wanted that, no cease-fire
for those who wanted one, no
guaranteed future for Vietnam
for those who wanted it, no
Democratic regime in the South
for those who wanted that, no
sign of a North Vietnamese
surrender for those who wanted
one...No matter what you want,
Nixon has failed to deliver,"
commented Shriver.
Calling the President the "veto
expert of the half-century", the
Democratic hopeful compared

Nixon with South Vietnamese
President Thieu. "Nixon saysq
won't sign', Thicu says 'I won't
sign';" declared Shriver," the
two masters of the veto have
found each other."
Following the rally, the
Shriver entourage entered the
Morris Mechanic Theatre for a
gala birthday celebration for
Hilda Shriver, the candidate's
mother. Billed as a nonpartisan
event, the theatre was filled with
guests invited for a combination
Senior Citizens Rally and
Birthday Party.
Folksinger Theodore Bikel
who acted as Master of
Ceremonies, was one of manY
who was entertaining the groupGovernor Marvin Mandel and
Mayor William Donald Schaefer
were on hand with proclamations
honoring Mrs. Shriver. Schaefer,
a Democrat, has refrained from
endorsing the McGovem—Shriver
ticket.
